article.headline: Hereâs what Exxonâs removal from the Dow says about the energy sector
article.body: Exxon Mobil Corp. shares extended their losses Tuesday, a day after the energy integrated company was removed from the Dow Jones Industrial Average to make room for Salesforce.com Inc. CRM, +2.21% Â , but the swap also says a lot about the energy sector. Exxon XOM, -1.47% Â stock traded as low as $41.27, on pace for its largest percent decrease in a week. The stock is down six of the past seven sessions, and down 41% year-to-date, which compares with losses around 1.3% for the Dow Jones Industrial Average. DJIA, +0.56% Â Exxon shares were the second worst performer in the Dow on Tuesday. Exxon has been on the 30-component, price-weighted index since 1928, as then the Standard Oil of New Jersey before its various iterations and the 1999 Exxon and Mobil merger. âMinorâ selling was to be expected from the change, as the Dow is not commonly used as a benchmark for actively managed funds, analyst Jennifer Rowland with Edward Jones said. Removing the company from the index, however, âis symbolic of just how far the energy sector has fallen over the past several years.â See also:Opinion: Exxon getting booted from the Dow Jones Industrial Average may be a blessing in disguise for its investors âGoing forward, (Chevron Corp. CVX, -1.62% ) will be the only energy stock on the DJIA. In the S&P 500, there are 5 stocks (Apple Inc. AAPL, +1.74%, Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.48%, Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +3.01%, Alphabet Inc. GOOG, +1.97% Â GOOGL, +1.82%, Â and Facebook Inc. FB, +0.26% ) that are individually larger than the entire U.S. energy sector â thatâs pretty sobering,â she said. S&P Dow Jones Indices announced the changes, effective Aug. 31, late Monday. Exxon as well as Pfizer Inc. PFE, -0.27% Â and Raytheon Technologies Corp. RTX, -1.46% Â will be out, the latter two replaced by biotech drugmaker Amgen Inc. AMGN, -1.41% Â and industrial conglomerate Honeywell International Inc. HON, +0.34% Â S&P Dow Jones said the changes were prompted by Appleâs decision to carry out a 4-for-1 stock split, reducing the indexâs tech-sector weighting. Related:Opinion: Apple investors: Watch out for the winnersâ curse Exxonâs ousting âis another blow to sentiment towards a sector that has been under intense selling pressure while losing relevance with the investment community over the past six years,â analysts at Tudor Pickering Holt said in a note Tuesday. The analysts rate Exxon stock a hold, reflecting the companyâs going further into debt to finance its dividend and pressure in key segments like refining, they said. The energy sector was the worst-hit sector on the S&P 500 index SPX, +0.87% Â on Tuesday, down nearly 2%. âAt a time when energy is a mere 2.5% of the S&P 500âs market cap, it seems incongruous that two oil and gas supermajors have been part of the Dow Jones Industrial Average,â said in a note Pavel Molchanov, an analyst at Raymond James. âWell, the powers that be at S&P Dow Jones Indices have finally addressed this anomaly.â Energy companies have battled twin shocks of years of oversupply and wrecked demand from the coronavirus pandemic. Thatâs alongside ongoing concerns about an eventual peak in oil demand, which has emerged before the pandemic, and ESG-related objections to fossil fuels, Molchanov said. âFor the record, our view on the oil market is more upbeat, and as such as we envision room for, on the whole, a healthy recovery in oil-levered equities into 2021, especially the latter half of the year,â he said. As to why Exxon and not Chevron is being removed, it may stem from the fact that Chevronâs share price is twice as high, since the DJIA incorporates share price in its weightings. But thatâs unlikely to be the only reason, he said. âFundamentally, Chevron is positioned much more straightforwardly as an oil producer: a high degree of operating leverage to commodity prices, and by contrast limited exposure to refining and almost none to chemicals,â he said. âThe index committee probably wanted to maintain some oil exposure, making Chevron the better choice to do so, especially given that chemical giant Dow Inc. DOW, -0.04% Â ... already represents the chemical industry in the index.â
